work.name: AMI Lab, University of Michigan
highlights: Project 1: Moiré-Based Schlieren Sensing in Real-World Environments

Developed MoiréLens, a Moiré-based Schlieren sensing framework that uses wallpaper patterns and low-cost cameras to visualize otherwise invisible heat plumes and gas-like flows in real kitchens, including an AutoMoiré calibration module and end-to-end pipelines for cooking-related ML tasks.
Project 2: Wearable IMU-based Activity Recognition and Motion Transcription

Explored wearable IMU-based activity recognition and motion transcription by surveying prior work, reproducing representative baselines, and prototyping transformer-based IMU localization that supports flexible device configurations.

work.name: DIDIS Lab, Shanghai Jiao Tong University
highlights: Project 1: Transformer-Based Motion Planning via Sequence-to-Sequence Generation

Worked on transformer-based motion planning, integrating geometric and collision-aware loss terms and building visualization tools to analyze how attention over obstacles affects path feasibility and trajectory quality.

projects.name: DreamMotion: High-Fidelity Subject Animation with Dynamic Motion Control
projects.summary: Course project for EECS 442 (Computer Vision) exploring text-to-video generation that disentangles subject identity and motion, using spatial and temporal LoRAs fused across diffusion timesteps.
highlights: Developed a text-to-video generation method on top of AnimateDiff that separates subject identity and motion.
Used a spatial LoRA for identity preservation and a temporal LoRA for motion control, dynamically fused across diffusion timesteps.

projects.name: Diffusion-Based Yellow-Face Emoji Generation
projects.summary: Course project for EECS 553 (Machine Learning) on diffusion-based emoji generation and evaluation.
highlights: Designed and implemented a pipeline that synthesizes a combinatorial emoji dataset, trains an EDM-based diffusion model, and evaluates generation quality and novelty with multiple metrics.
Ran ablation experiments over model size and training epochs, analyzing how FID/KID and MeanMSE evolve during training to characterize memorization versus novelty.

projects.name: Network Simulation
projects.summary: Course project for EECS 489 (Computer Networks) implementing key networking components and experiments.
highlights: Simulated network topologies in Mininet and wrote C++ socket programs to measure RTT and throughput, reproducing bufferbloat and analyzing its impact on latency-sensitive flows.
Built a video proxy with load balancing and adaptive DASH streaming to improve quality of experience under varying bandwidth.
Implemented a POX-based SDN controller, a TCP-like reliable transport over UDP, and an L3 router supporting ARP and ICMP.

projects.name: AI-Driven AR Drawing Assistant (SketchGenie)
projects.summary: Course project for EECS 498 (AI-Enabled Mixed Reality) building an AR system that turns voice descriptions into AI-generated line drawings projected onto paper.
highlights: Designed and implemented an AR system that converts voice descriptions into AI-generated line drawings projected onto physical paper for tracing.
Implemented a GPT-4o + DALL·E 3 image pipeline and a Meta Quest 3 AR module (Unity + OpenCV/ArUco + solvePnP) for marker-based projection alignment.

projects.name: Bluetooth-Controlled Robotics Vehicle
projects.summary: Freshman mechanical innovation competition project at SJTU, developing a Bluetooth-controlled robotics vehicle.
highlights: Developed an Arduino-based Bluetooth control system using the HC-06 module for a PS2 controller.
Designed circuits integrated with the mechanical chassis and collaborated on assembly and testing.
Won First Prize in the 13th "Liming Cup" SJTU Freshman Mechanical Innovation Competition.
